Chapter on Impermanence, Part 2

At that time, the people heard what the Buddha said, and all gave rise to the pure, irreversible practice.
It is like a person holding a staff, herding and feeding cattle, old age and death are also like this,
Also nourishing the life of a worm.

Formerly the Buddha was in the realm of Magadha, in the city of RÄjagá¹›ha. The Buddha took Ä€nanda, put on his robe and held his alms bowl, and on the way he saw someone driving a thousand cows to good grass, watching over them with smoke.

Although they enjoy water and grass, nurturing their skin, they only hasten their lives and bring no benefit to themselves.

The Buddha returned to the monastery and admonished the assembly of disciples of the four groups with this cause and condition. Among them, more than two hundred people heard the Dharma, understood it, attained the six spiritual powers, and became arhats.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:

Those who should hear parables, this verse is for them.
Those who are liberated by timely measurements of meaning, therefore it is said: It is like a person holding a staff, their affairs are like this.
This day has already passed, life then follows and decreases, like a fish with little water,

The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:

When people are in the world, their practices are not the same and their views are also different. One day has passed and people's lives follow and decrease. Although they live for a hundred years, half of it is spent in sleep.
He then spoke this verse with the assembly:
If people wish to establish virtue, day and night should not be wasted,
Day and night are as fast as lightning, people's lives are as swift as this.

At that time, those who gathered to observe this meaning and contemplate practice, the day and night having passed, the conditions for death are difficult to calculate. Foolish people rely on and become attached to receiving existence. They should remember to diligently increase their courageous mind without losing their essence. Therefore, it is said:
This day has already passed, and life then follows in decreasing, like a fish with little water,

You bhiká¹£us should understand this principle. The great ocean and rivers still dry up. The great fish with ten thousand blades exposes its back outside. How much more so for this little water, which does not flow?
Sometimes the ditches and streams overflow with torrential rain?
The current rushes downward, the sound shaking the four directions. The person on the other shore calls out, but does not hear the sound. The person here calls out, but does not hear the sound.

Sometimes the water in the ditches and streams is completely gone, without any remaining. Although the beings of the four destinies receive their physical forms, their lives then follow in decreasing, like a fish with little water. What joy is there in this?

Some sentient beings have extremely long lifespans. The lifespan of the gods is 84,000 kalpas. The lifespan in hell is one kalpa. The lifespan of animals is the same as in hell. The lifespan of hungry ghosts is immeasurable.

At that time, the ghost replied:

The lifespan of hungry ghosts is immeasurable and has no fixed limit, but the lifespan of humans is at most a hundred years, and even then few live that long. Therefore it is said, What joy is there for a fish in a little water?
Therefore, it is said separately that humans do not fall into the four destinies.

In the past, the Buddha was in the Jeta Grove of Anathapindika's Park in the country of Shravasti.

At that time, a man with a large retinue and luxurious carriage followed a great guide to go to sea to collect treasures. Other small merchants followed him, providing food, drink, and entertainment to the poor, ascetics, and Brahmins.
After obtaining treasures from the sea, they returned to the shore and enjoyed themselves, eating and drinking without interruption day after day.

At that time, the great guide said to him:
You are now wealthy in the world, with abundant treasures, few can compare. Why do you torment yourself and refuse to eat?
When people are in the world, they should practice two things:
First, to give generously, second, to eat themselves.
When that person heard this, he did not accept it in his mind, but rather harbored resentment and gradually became depressed. He said to the guide:
If I eat, I will not be able to provide for my wife, children, and family. Later, when I encounter a serious illness, I will not be able to return home, and I will die on the way.
That great guide spoke this verse:
When people are stingy and greedy, they hoard wealth and possessions, thinking of their family as enemies,

At that time, the World-Honored One observed with his pure divine eye, free from defilements, and saw that the guide had made merit and was gathering treasures, but died on the way.

there is no relative to rely on.

At that time, the great assembly heard what the Buddha said, their minds opened up and their thoughts enlightened. They made merit and established virtue, rescuing the destitute and needy. They observed the precepts and cultivated the precepts, never neglecting the three months and six days of the year. They made offerings of the four requisites: clothing, food, bedding, and medicine for illness. If they needed clothing, they gave them clothing. If they needed food, they gave them food. The seven precious treasures of wealth and jewels, gold, silver, precious stones, carnelian, agate, pearls, and amber, were given to those who sought them without going against their wishes. Those who came from afar, stayed for a long time, and passed by were all provided for. They also gave flowers, incense, and cosmetics without any stinginess.

Countless great assemblies became disgusted with birth and death, removed greedy thoughts, upheld the faith firmly, left the household life to cultivate the path, cultivated the supreme Dharma without any thought of turning back, and each attained the path of arhatship in due course.
Thousands and hundreds, not just one, of clansmen, men, and women, accumulate wealth and possessions,
all of which will decline and be lost.

Sentient beings dwell in the world, running in the four directions, greedily seeking wealth and goods, giving rise to desires without satiation. In the height of summer, they brave the heat; in winter, they walk through severe frost. Hungry and cold, they suffer hardships and worries. They lose ten thousand times and gain only once, yet they still rejoice in themselves. The fruition of the mind of giving is difficult, and their intentions are not enlightened. Having not eaten themselves, they do not give to others. Although they have abundant treasures, it is no different from having none.

A person sitting in meditation is adorned with the seven treasures. Although they look at it with their eyes, their minds do not find it sweet or enjoyable. Because of stinginess and greed, they transmigrate through birth and death, from this world to the next world.

At that time, the World-Honored One used his heavenly eye, which is pure and free from defilements, to observe sentient beings running in the four directions, greedily seeking wealth and goods without considering future consequences, all of them deluded by foolishness and mistaken views.

At that time, the World-Honored One spoke this verse in the great assembly:
Thousands and hundreds, not one, sons and daughters of the clans, accumulating wealth and possessions,

At that time, in the assembly, there were millions and tens of millions of people who heard what the Buddha said, focused their minds to listen and accept, and each according to their thoughts attained the fruit of realization.
What is constant will all end, what is high will also fall, what comes together will separate,
what is born will have death.
Formerly the Buddha was in the Jeta Grove of Anathapindika's Garden in the kingdom of Shravasti.
At that time, a certain brahman came to where the World-Honored One was, exchanged greetings, and sat to one side.

The Buddha told the brÄhman:

In this, brÄhman!

At that time, those sentient beings, tainted by these three things, experience untimely disasters from wind and rain, and poisonous floods. The seeds they plant each lose their proper timing, and do not ripen.

If the food that those beings eat, whether raw or cooked, is full of diseases and epidemics, and the dead fill the roads beyond count, this is called the first reason, brahmin, that causes the beings of this world to become increasingly few and diminished, and one does not see their flourishing in the human world.

Wind and rain are untimely, disasters are rampant, the seeds sown are lost and not harvested, they do not ripen and sprouts do not grow, and many people starve to death in famine. This is called the second reason, brahmin, that causes the beings of this world to become increasingly few and diminished, and one does not see their flourishing.
Furthermore, brahmin!

Now, the king is greedy and unjust, stingy and jealous, and adheres to wrong views. His governance is out of control, and he is insatiable in his pursuit of territory. He invades other countries and harms others, using swords, spears, and arrows to kill countless beings beyond measure. This is how, brahmin, the three causes lead to disasters and famines among the living beings.
Having spoken this, the Buddha told MaudgalyÄyana:

He replied:

The brahmin replied:

MaudgalyÄyana spoke a verse, saying:

The brahmin heard the verse and his mind opened up, his thoughts understood, and he immediately entered the path. Therefore it is said, What is constant all ends, what is high also falls, what comes together will separate, those who are born have death.

At that time, there was a widowed mother who had lost her only son. She was overcome with grief and sorrow, her mind confused and disoriented, like a mad person with no understanding.

The widowed mother then went to where the Buddha was, made prostrations, knelt for a long time, and said to the World-Honored One:
I have few children and only one son. He suddenly became seriously ill and passed away, leaving me with unbearable grief as a mother and son.
I only wish that the World-Honored One would

The Buddha told the widowed mother:

Having heard this, the widowed mother joyfully and excitedly entered the city of Shravasti and went to every household in the streets, saying:ğŸ”½I have come to ask for fire.

The people replied:

Every house they went to said they had died.
Their bodies and spirits were tired and their search was unsuccessful, so they returned home, took their little child to the World-Honored One, bowed their heads at his feet and said:
We received the order to enter the city and beg for fire from every household, but they all said they had died, so we returned empty-handed.
The Buddha told the widowed mother:
There are four causes and conditions in a person's life in the world that cannot be kept for long.
What are the four?

First, what is constant will certainly become impermanent; second, the wealthy and noble will certainly become poor and humble; third, those who come together will certainly part; fourth, the strong and healthy will certainly die.
Approaching death, heading towards death, being pulled by death, there is no escape from this suffering.
The Buddha said to the widowed mother:
Why do you not worry about yourself now?

The widowed mother said to the Buddha:
I now love my child to the marrow of my bones. For the sake of my child, I would not begrudge my own life.

At that time, the World-Honored One, wishing to transform that person and cause them to awaken, manifested four large fire pits surrounding the widowed mother's body. The heat of the fire pressed against her body, and she used her child as a shield. The child also cried out in unbearable pain from the heat.
The Buddha said to the widowed mother:
You have just said that you love your child to the marrow of your bones, and would rather lose your own life than let your child die;
The heat of the fire pressing against you is difficult to bear, so you should just endure it yourself?
Why use your child as a shield?
The small fires of humans are nothing to speak of, but the fires of hell burn with immeasurable pain.

The suffering of animals is due to their stupidity and delusion, while the suffering of hungry ghosts is due to their meager blessings and hunger. Only those who can benefit themselves can practice the Way and cultivate various wholesome roots, such as giving, being generous, observing precepts, and practicing patience. They will not be reborn in the hells, animal realm, or hungry ghost realm to experience various sufferings, but will receive the blessings of humans and gods and gradually approach nirvana.
